author: By Ghazaleh Moayedi
title: How Texas Has Made My Job of Helping Women More Dangerous
description: Navigating care for pregnancy and abortion in Texas is impossible.
content: It’s not brave for me to be an abortion provider in Texas. This is my home, too. I have a lot of support from my community. I work at several types of clinics here and in Oklahoma — independent ones, mostly. I went to medical school with the express intent to provide abortions in my home state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Global Supply Shortages Reach All the Way to a Haitian Aid Group
description: Continuing disruption to factory production and bottlenecks in shipping are leaving nonprofit groups short of goods for vulnerable communities worldwide.
content: In the face of bewildering and enduring shortages of goods throughout the global economy, even aid organizations like food banks and clothing distributors are caught in the chaos. Many are struggling to secure what they need, amplifying scarcity in vulnerable communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: The Biden administration will raise the cap on refugee admissions to 125,000.
description: The move indicates the president’s intention to open the country’s doors after four years in which the Trump administration sought to prevent refugees from settling in the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden intends to increase to 125,000 the number of refugees who can enter the United States in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, the State Department announced on Monday, making good on his campaign pledge to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: In a First, Washington Will Draft Rules on Workplace Heat Dangers
description: The move, aimed at protecting workers in sectors like agriculture and construction, reflects a growing recognition of the health threats posed by global warming.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is opening an effort across federal agencies to address the health impacts from heat, including the first ever labor standard aimed at protecting workers from extreme heat, as part of a growing recognition of the dangers posed by warming temperatures caused by climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Where NASA Will Send Its First Robotic Moon Rover to Search for Ice
description: The agency picked the Nobile crater near the lunar south pole to seek frozen water that will be essential to future astronaut missions.
content: NASA has been planning for years to send a robotic rover to the moon’s polar regions. Water ice trapped at the bottoms of craters there could be a boon to future visiting astronauts, providing water to drink, air to breathe and rocket fuel to propel them back to Earth or even farther out into the solar system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Glitch Reveals Ballot Choices of N.Y.C. Voters, Including Mayor’s Son
description: The Board of Elections inadvertently allowed the mayoral primary votes of 378 New Yorkers, including Dante de Blasio, to become public, a report found.
content: When a well-known 20-something New Yorker cast his Democratic primary ballot in June, he had every reason to assume that no one would know his choice for mayor — a point of interest for many, since his father was the current mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Macron Takes on U.S., a Big Gamble Even for a Bold Risk-Taker
description: For President Emmanuel Macron of France, a debacle over a lost submarine deal with Australia suggests that the NATO alliance is debilitated through lack of trust.
content: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France has gambled big. He has directed his foreign minister to use language not typically associated with diplomacy, let alone diplomacy between allies, in describing American actions: “lies,” “duplicity,” “brutality” and “contempt.” He has recalled the French ambassador to the United States, a first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Why did Justin Trudeau call for an early election?
description: His opponents have denounced the move as unnecessary and potentially dangerous amid a continuing pandemic.
content: Canadians often grumble about federal elections called before schedule, as is the case with Monday’s vote. But usually the complaints die out after the first week of campaigning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: The Washington Post is adding 41 new editing jobs as part of its expansion.
description: The roles include two new deputy managing editors and a number of positions for other editors as the news outlet expands its national and international coverage.
content: The Washington Post is expanding its editor ranks as it pushes forward with plans for growth in national and international coverage under its new executive editor, Sally Buzbee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: An American Journalist Sits in Prison as Myanmar Suppresses Dissent
description: Danny Fenster on Monday was ordered to remain in confinement. The court hearing marked his 120th day in custody after being detained by the junta in May.
content: Danny Fenster, an American journalist who was arrested in May as he prepared to leave Myanmar, was ordered Monday to remain in prison as police investigate a vague accusation that he disseminated information that could be harmful to the military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: U.S. to allow vaccinated foreigners.
content: The Biden administration will lift travel restrictions starting in November for foreign residents who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Michaela Coel wins best writing in a limited series for ‘I May Destroy You.’
description: It was Coel’s first Emmy Award and she is the first Black woman to win in the category.
content: After it was controversially snubbed by the Golden Globes, the HBO limited series “I May Destroy You” received some measure of awards justice when it received six Primetime Emmy nominations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Post-Brexit Britain on the world stage.
content: A maritime security alliance between Britain, the U.S. and Australia has caused anger and recrimination across three continents, bringing relations between France and the U.S. to their lowest point in decades. Britain has emerged as the unlikely winner of the agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Watch These Two New Shows Starting This Week
description: Fall TV is back, and our critic recommends a thoughtful reboot and a new scripted series about reality shows.
content: This is the web version of our Watching newsletter, in which Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations like these every Monday and Friday. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for Watching here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Why My NFT Toad Brought Me Joy
description: There’s something funny about a digital amphibian who might one day pay for my retirement. But it’s more than that.
content: It’s difficult to admit in polite company, but I have a small collection of nonfungible tokens (NFTs). I’ll spare all of you the lengthy throat-clearing about cryptocurrency, provenance and some litany of explainer clauses and just say that an NFT is more or less a digital deed that says you own something unique on the internet. To date, NFTs have mostly taken the form of digital images, which, in turn, can sell for tens of millions of dollars in the same way that a painting might sell for tens of millions of dollars at an art auction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugo Lindgren
title: The 18-Year Wait for New Wrens Music Is Over. Sort Of.
description: The New Jersey indie rockers promised a final album. Their day jobs and families have expanded, but the band’s two creative forces kept writing — separately.
content: How do you know it’s time to pull the plug on the band you started as a teenager? Is it when you get married and have kids and buy a house in the deep New Jersey ’burbs? Or when you have a job so serious, they move you to Singapore for two years? Or when you turn 50?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roggeveen
title: Australia Is Making a Risky Bet on the U.S.
description: Australia has thrust itself into a central role in America’s rivalry with China.
content: The United States did not directly mention China in announcing its historic new security partnership with Australia and Britain last week, but it didn’t have to. The defense deal is a clear escalation and indication that Washington views Beijing as an adversary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: The Mannings Give TV Sports Yet Another Alternate Viewing Option
description: ESPN has the quarterbacks Peyton and Eli Manning. CBS has the slime and SpongeBob allure of Nickelodeon. A boxing upstart even got Trump. For viewers, it’s ever more options beyond just watching the game.
content: Midway through the telecast of this N.F.L. season’s first Monday night game, Eli Manning asked his brother Peyton what he would do when a coach called a play he did not like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Drake’s ‘Certified Lover Boy’ Holds at No. 1 for a Second Week
description: The rapper’s latest album repeats at the top of the Billboard 200, and Kacey Musgraves’s “Star-Crossed” opens at No. 3.
content: In its second week out, Drake’s hit new album, “Certified Lover Boy,” lost 61 percent of its sales, but it still holds at No. 1 on Billboard’s chart, while the latest LP from the Grammy-winning country star Kacey Musgraves opens at No. 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Austrian Comfort Food to Go
description: Café Sabarsky will now offer meal kits for takeaway, featuring Austro-Hungarian favorites like chicken paprikash and beef goulash.
content: Café Sabarsky in the Neue Galerie is offering food to take away for the first time. Meal kits serving two offer specialties from Austria, Hungary and Germany, like chicken paprikash and beef goulash, both with spätzle ($58 each); and roasted bratwurst with sauerkraut and potatoes, and Bavarian sausage with a pretzel ($36 each). There’s also a vegetarian spätzle dish with mushrooms ($36). Christopher Engel, the executive chef, prepares all the ingredients and provides instructions for reheating and assembly. Desserts ($18 to $20), also for two, are apple strudel, Sacher torte and a layered nougat Mozart cake with pistachio and chocolate. Whole cakes are also sold to go. As an optional alternative to the usual takeout containers, the museum is selling handsome reusable double-layered stainless steel tiffins ($28) in which the meals can be packed. Ordering is by phone, 212-288-0665, or email, cafe@neuegalerie.org, 24 hours in advance. Pickup is available during Café Sabarsky hours, Thursday through Sunday 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. and Monday 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: History Repeats Itself. First as Tragedy, Second as Farce, Then as God Knows What.
description: Sept. 18 was no Jan. 6.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, there was an old leftie saying: “Suppose they gave a war and nobody came.” I was thinking about that over the weekend when we were anticipating a big right-wing follow-up to the storming of the Capitol in January. And hardly anyone showed up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu and Heather Murphy
title: The U.S. travel industry welcomes the Biden administration’s changes to travel rules.
description: The 18-month travel ban on travelers from Europe, China, Iran, South Africa, Brazil and India has been crippling for the industry,
content: The U.S. travel industry breathed a sigh of relief on Monday after the Biden administration said it would ease longstanding restrictions on international travelers, allowing those who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus to visit the country beginning in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai and Ian Austen
title: Canada’s Election: What to Know
description: Justin Trudeau will remain the prime minister. But his Liberal Party fell short of a majority.
content: Since Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada called a snap election last month — two years ahead of schedule — he has struggled to explain why he thinks it’s necessary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: At 75, the Ojai Music Festival Stays Focused on the Future
description: This storied California haven of contemporary classical music returned, organized by the composer John Adams.
content: OJAI, Calif. — Returning is a process. Rarely is it linear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Maman Reveals Its Cookie Formula in New Cookbook
description: Soups, sandwiches and that chocolate chip cookie are all here in “Maman: The Cookbook,” from the downtown Manhattan cafe.
content: I fell in love with Maman, a cafe and bakery dressed in toile de Jouy, from the minute it opened on the edge of SoHo in 2014. And when the cookbook by the owners Elisa Marshall and Benjamin Sormonte, written with Lauren Salkeld, crossed my desk I decided that if it had the nutty chocolate chip cookie recipe and it worked, the book was worth recommending. Yes, and yes. The thick batter is not so easy to assemble but the effort is worth the results: more than a dozen giant cookies (more than four inches in diameter). I made smaller ones with half the batter and they turned out fine. This is not a book to consult for dinner; most of the recipes, like the cafe itself, which now has several locations in New York and Canada, suit lunch, all-day dining and light suppers. Salads and sandwiches abound. I also recommend the red wine, mushroom and onion soup; the cherry tomato, caramelized onion and feta tart; the olive oil-blood orange loaf; and the spiced turmeric tea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: The Daily News gets an ‘as-needed’ editor until a new one is found.
description: Andrew Julien, the editor and publisher of The Hartford Courant, will replace Robert York, the editor in chief of New York’s Daily News, on an interim basis.
content: Robert York, the editor in chief of The Daily News of New York, is being replaced on an interim and “as-needed” basis by Andrew Julien, the editor and publisher of its corporate sibling The Hartford Courant, who will remain in that job while a search for a permanent editor takes place, an executive at the publisher of the newspapers said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: ‘America’s Oldest Park Ranger’ Is Only Her Latest Chapter
description: Betty Reid Soskin has fought to ensure that American history includes the stories that get overlooked. As she turns 100, few stories have been more remarkable than hers.
content: The Rosie the Riveter / World War II Home Front National Historical Park, which sprawls across the former shipyards in Richmond, Calif., on the northeast edge of San Francisco Bay, tells the enormous story of the largest wartime mobilization in American history and the sweeping social changes it sparked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ethan Hauser, Maria Cramer and Michael Levenson
title: Who is Gabrielle Petito?
description: Gabrielle Petito had worked as a pharmacy technician to save money for a crosscountry trip with her boyfriend.
content: On Sept. 11, the family of Gabrielle Petito reported her missing to the North Port, Fla., police department. She seemed to have disappeared in the western United States during a cross-country trip with her fiancé, Brian Laundrie, who returned to his home in North Port without Ms. Petito, 22, on Sept. 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Does the U.S. Economy Still Need Booster Shots?
description: This week, the Federal Reserve may hint at an answer.
content: The experts disagree. Some say the protection that has already been provided is enough. Others say a booster is necessary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: How the U.S. Helped, and Hampered, the Escape of Afghan Journalists
description: The secretary of state cites a “massive effort” by the government, but people involved in the evacuation instead describe bureaucratic snags.
content: As American news organizations scrambled to evacuate their Afghan journalists and their families last month, I reported that those working for The New York Times had found refuge not in New York or Washington, but in Mexico City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: They watch him on TikTok, but will young supporters turn out for Jagmeet Singh?
description: The party has focused on the Indigenous vote; also on economic issues like income distribution and taxing the ultra-wealthy.
content: Ditching a collared dress shirt for a sleeveless hoodie, Jagmeet Singh, the leader of the left-leaning New Democratic Party, sways to the music in a recent TikTok video recreating a viral dance trend, with text overlaid about how youth voters are “going to make history” this election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and James Dobbins
title: In Texas Border Town, Residents Feel Impact of Migrant Crisis
description: The influx of thousands of migrants has led to squalor under a bridge, and a dispirited town beyond it.
content: DEL RIO, Texas — On Friday afternoon, Jose Rodriguez stood near a fence that was steps away from the Rio Grande and tried to comprehend what was happening in his small border city: a steady stream of flashing red and blue lights speeding down a side road, each vehicle bringing heavily armed officers to guard thousands of desperate migrants huddled in a shantytown near and under Del Rio’s international bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: The human remains were found in a remote, but popular, camping destination.
description: Ms. Petito was last known to be driving toward the area with her fiancé as they embarked on a cross-country trip, according to her family.
content: The human remains believed to belong to Gabrielle “Gabby” Petito were found on the eastern boundary of the Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming, the F.B.I. said, an area that her family previously said was the last place they knew she was driving toward with her fiancé as they embarked on a cross-country trip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Festival Presents Food on Film
description: The FoodxFilm Festival, supported by the United Nations Food Systems Summit, puts the focus on documentary film.
content: FoodxFilm Festival is a new global, virtual festival of food-related documentary films and series, mostly full-length, that examine social issues, agriculture, the environment, the sea and the future of food. It starts on Sunday and continues on Oct. 2 and 3. Among the films are “The Taste of Desire,” a global look at oysters; “When Tomatoes Met Wagner” about Greek farmers in a small village; and David Chang’s series made by Morgan Neville, “The Next Thing You Eat.” Several panels to discuss food issues will be part of the festival. It is free of charge but registration is required. The films and panels are available to stream on the festival’s website  for 24 hours after they appear. The festival was created by the Guild of Future Architects, in association with the Rockefeller Foundation, and is supported by the United Nations Food Systems Summit, the World Food Forum, and Good Food for All.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Lawsuits are filed against a Texas doctor who said he performed an abortion.
description: The suits, brought by men in Arkansas and Illinois, appear to be the first under a state law that bans most abortions after the six-week mark.
content: HOUSTON — A man in Arkansas and another in Illinois on Monday filed what appeared to be the first legal actions under a strict new abortion law in Texas that is enforced by ordinary citizens, regardless of where they live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: De Gustibus Returns to Herald Square
description: The cooking school inside Macy’s found the Zoom option to be so popular during the pandemic, it’s keeping it when the classes return IRL.
content: De Gustibus, the cooking school with classes led by chefs, has been at it successfully for more than 40 years. For the past pandemic year their virtual sessions have been popular that even now that the school is returning to in-person instruction in its kitchen at Macy’s Herald Square, the company is offering a remote instruction option on Zoom. For the start of the new season the chefs on board are Jiho Kim and Kelly Nam of Joomak Banjum, with sweet and savory Korean-Chinese dishes (Sept. 23); Ayesha Nurdjaja of Shukette, with Middle Eastern fare (Oct. 5); and Christine Lau of Kimika, blending Japanese and Italian cuisines (Oct. 6). All 90-minute classes meet at 6 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish
title: Bezos Puts $1 Billion of $10 Billion Climate Pledge Into Conservation
description: A year after announcing the Bezos Earth Fund, the Amazon founder detailed how some of the money would be spent.
content: Jeff Bezos, the Amazon founder and one of the world’s richest men, announced plans on Monday for $1 billion in conservation spending in places like the Congo Basin, the Andes and tropical parts of the Pacific Ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York City Schools Strategy: Test More, but Keep Classrooms Open
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced weekly testing of students and relaxed quarantine rules but continued to resist mandatory vaccination of schoolchildren.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Monday that New York City would take two new steps to address fears over the full reopening of schools: require weekly coronavirus testing of unvaccinated students and relax quarantine rules to keep more students in classrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Walther
title: Norm Macdonald’s Comedy Was Quite Christian
description: His faith is key to understanding his comic legacy.
content: The relationship between Christianity and stand-up comedy has been going steadily downhill for half a century. In the 1960s, this was still a country in which Bishop Fulton Sheen could take part in the Friars Club roast of Milton Berle, and Tom Lehrer could give Catholicism a goofy but informed ribbing in his song “Vatican Rag,” which appeared on an LP that spent 51 weeks on the Billboard album charts. These days, with the notable exception of Stephen Colbert, it is difficult to imagine many mainstream comedians engaging with Christianity at all, except in the context of lazy jokes about the Catholic sexual abuse crisis or the political views of stereotypical Southern evangelicals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Boxer Manny Pacquiao Joins Philippine Presidential Race
description: The country’s best-known athlete already holds a seat in the Senate and has faced tough opposition from President Rodrigo Duterte.
content: MANILA — The former boxing champion Manny Pacquiao has shuffled his way into the presidential race in the Philippines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In Karl Ove Knausgaard’s Horror-Tinged New Novel, a Mesmerizing Star Appears in the Sky
description: “The Morning Star” chews on big ideas about God and mortality while its characters react to a bright and eerie new presence above them.
content: “Cheep-cheep, you fat creep,” a bird says to a journalist, or so the journalist thinks, in “The Morning Star,” Karl Ove Knausgaard’s apocalyptic new novel. “Cheep-cheep, and no sleep.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Cuomo Ally Resigns From Post as State Watchdog
description: Letizia Tagliafierro, the former inspector general, is the latest in a string of high-profile departures, as allies and appointees of the former governor leave state government.
content: The New York State inspector general resigned on Friday, becoming the latest in a string of high-profile departures from state government as allies and appointees of former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo follow him into private life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Reuben Klamer, Mastermind of the Game of Life, Dies at 99
description: He developed an estimated 200 toys and other items, including a phaser rifle for “Star Trek.” But his best-known product was a game for “literally everyone on earth.”
content: Reuben Klamer, an inventor who dreamed up the Game of Life and many other toys and games that entertained young baby boomers in the pre-internet 1950s and ’60s, as well as their children in the ’80s and ’90s, died on Sept. 14 at his home in the La Jolla neighborhood of San Diego. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York City will increase testing at schools and relax quarantine rules.
description: The city will introduce weekly coronavirus testing at all public schools starting next week, as officials try to strengthen safety protocols, Mayor Bill de Blasio said.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Monday that New York City would take two new steps to address fears over the full reopening of schools: require weekly coronavirus testing of unvaccinated students and relax quarantine rules to keep more students in classrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘Mare of Easttown’ takes both supporting actor awards for limited series.
description: Julianne Nicholson won for her role as Lori and Evan Peters for his performance as Detective Colin Zabel. Both were first-time nominees.
content: “Mare of Easttown” was one of the buzziest limited series of the year, and it received 16 Emmy nominations, including for best limited or anthology series. Thus far Sunday night,  the HBO crime drama has already claimed both supporting acting awards for a limited or anthology series or movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard, Michael Gold and Winnie Hu
title: How Can New York City Prepare for the Next Ida? Here’s a To-Do List.
description: The recipe sounds simple: Improve drainage. Use plants, tanks and barriers to slow water. But it takes money and cooperation.
content: When the remnants of Hurricane Ida swept into New York this month, the storm’s ferocity shocked the city. Even with meteorologists warning of intense rains and flooding, the swiftness with which the storm turned streets into rushing — and deadly — rivers caught officials and residents off guard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $900,000 Homes in California
description: A Craftsman house in Sacramento, a brand-new home in Oakland and a two-bedroom condominium in Santa Monica.
content: This house is a block away from Sutter’s Fort State Historic Park, where costumed interpreters working on the grounds and in the main adobe structure demonstrate aspects of life in 1840s Sacramento. Today, the area is mostly residential, apart from Sutter General Hospital and the shops and restaurants clustered along the main avenues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: The F.D.A. is likely to make its long-awaited decision on Pfizer boosters this week.
description: The agency’s ruling on who should be eligible for a third Pfizer-BioNTech dose is one of a series of vaccine decisions expected in the coming weeks.
content: The Food and Drug Administration is likely to authorize Pfizer-BioNTech booster shots this week for many Americans at high risk of falling seriously ill from the coronavirus, now that a key advisory committee has voted to recommend the measure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canadians will decide if Justin Trudeau’s political gamble pays off.
description: It was a political calculation. And on Monday Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will find out if it succeeded.
content: It was a political calculation. And on Monday Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will find out if it succeeded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Is Your Reaction to Efforts to Limit Teaching on Race in Schools?
description: Legislation opposing critical race theory spread across the country this spring and summer. How will these laws affect you, your school and the nation?
content: To date, more than 20 states — including New Hampshire, Michigan, Texas, Florida, South Carolina and Arkansas — have introduced regulations that restrict teaching about race and racism. Some of these laws have taken aim at what has been labeled critical race theory — an academic legal framework for understanding racism in the United States developed during the 1980s — while others are crafted more broadly to address what they call “divisive concepts.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: How Tax Giants Write Their Own Rules
description: The biggest accounting firms take advantage of the government’s revolving door.
content: There’s a well-oiled revolving door between the largest accounting firms in the U.S. and the Treasury Department, The Times’s Jesse Drucker and Danny Hakim report. The cycling of professionals between the public and private sectors is nothing new, but the ability of the biggest tax advisers to embed their employees inside the government’s most important tax policy jobs has largely escaped public scrutiny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Kenneth Schoen, ‘Linchpin’ in Criminal Justice Reform, Dies at 89
description: In Minnesota, New York and nationally, he pushed for better conditions for prison inmates and more options for “community-based corrections.”
content: Kenneth F. Schoen, a former probation officer who helped shift the nation’s criminal justice agenda for nonviolent offenders from fixed sentences in faraway prisons to flexible alternatives in their own communities, died on Sept. 1 in Duluth, Minn. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Climate, Covid and Biden’s Challenged Credibility Underline U.N.’s Big Week
description: The United Nations General Assembly session, the world’s biggest diplomatic convocation, will commandeer attention with a lineup of leader speeches starting Tuesday.
content: The United Nations convenes its annual speeches by world leaders on Tuesday against a backdrop of seemingly irreversible planet warming, polarized superpower relations and a tenacious pandemic that has worsened the global rich-poor divide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan and Annie Correal
title: Long Island Man Targeted Latino Immigrants for Attack, Police Say
description: The authorities said the 19-year-old man chose victims at gathering places for day laborers.
content: A Long Island man was charged with several hate crimes after he picked up Hispanic day laborers at places they were known to gather, drove them to secluded areas and attacked them, the police said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh and Dana Goldstein
title: Pfizer says its vaccine is safe for children 5 to 11. Will parents buy in?
description: Children have so far been vaccinated at lower rates than adults, and polling indicates greater hesitation among parents of younger children.
content: With Pfizer-BioNTech’s announcement on Monday that its coronavirus vaccine had been shown to be safe and effective in low doses in children ages 5 to 11, a major question looms: How many parents will have it given to their children?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: What Is 23andMe Doing With Your DNA?
description: C.E.O. Anne Wojcicki grapples with the ethical questions that come with building a business on customers’ personal information.
content: Anne Wojcicki is sitting on a treasure trove of genetic data. Wojcicki, a co-founder and the chief executive of the genetic testing company 23andMe, has led it through 14 years in which it has collected data from millions of customers through at-home DNA spit test kits. In 2018 the company announced a collaboration with GlaxoSmithKline to use this anonymized, aggregated data to develop pharmaceutical drugs — and attracted a $300 million investment from the pharmaceutical giant. And in June, when Wojcicki took the company public, it was valued at $3.5 billion. In some ways, it’s a standard Silicon Valley play: Lure customers in with the promise of democratizing information, then quickly moving to monetize that information. But what are the implications when the information at stake is your DNA?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: What we know about Brian Laundrie, the fiancé of Gabrielle Petito.
description: Mr. Laundrie, who is missing, was the last known person to have been with Ms. Petito before she went missing, according to the authorities.
content: Brian Laundrie, a Long Island native, is Gabrielle Petito’s fiancé and a “person of interest” in her disappearance, as he was the last person known to have been with her before she went missing, according to the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Canopy Beds
description: Because a canopy bed is ‘like a cocoon’ — and this fall, we could all use a little of that.
content: Any bed can provide a place to sleep, but a canopy bed does something more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: The Fall TV Season Is Back, Smaller Than Ever
description: The broadcast networks’ premiere week returns after a pandemic hiatus. Here’s what there is to see, from a new version of “The Wonder Years” to the latest addition to the “NCIS”verse.
content: The fall television season is back! Or is it, really?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: With ‘The Crown,’ Netflix Finally Takes the Emmys Throne
description: The lush Netflix series chronicling the British royal family took home the four major acting awards as well as best drama. “Ted Lasso,” on Apple TV+, and “Mare of Easttown,” on HBO, also scored numerous wins.
content: At long last, the streaming platforms were triumphant at the Emmys, with Netflix and AppleTV+ taking major awards in drama, comedy and limited series as Television Academy voters acknowledged a profound shift in entertainment, from the channel-flipping days of traditional TV to the 21st-century mode of click-and-watch binge viewing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Worthen
title: The Fight Over Tenure Is Not Really About Tenure
description: It’s a proxy for a larger debate about the meaning of academic freedom and the priorities of higher education.
content: Why should universities guarantee jobs to a bunch of elitists who study esoteric subjects and brainwash students with left-wing politics? This critique of tenure in higher education is as old as tenure itself, and it’s gaining ground. In recent years, governing boards and legislators in several states have attempted to ban tenure or curtail its power — sometimes succeeding, as in Wisconsin. In the American labor market, where employers have unusually wide latitude to hire and fire at will, it’s not hard for politicians to channel popular resentment toward a small class of workers with relatively strong protections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag, Patrick McGeehan, Ceylan Yeginsu and Heather Murphy
title: N.Y.C.’s tourism industry, hit hard by the pandemic, sees a reason for hope with changes to travel rules.
description: Only 2.4 million international visitors came to New York City in 2020, a steep decline from 13.5 million in the year before the pandemic.
content: Tourism officials in New York City welcomed the news on Monday that restrictions on travel to the United States by those fully vaccinated against the coronavirus would be eased in November. It was a sign of hope for a city whose famed retail corridors and hotel and leisure sectors have been pummeled without international tourists during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Tepper
title: Glimpses of ‘Lost Tribe’ Jewish Communities in India and Myanmar
description: Often overlooked, the communities in South and Southeast Asia complicate notions of Jewish identity while emphasizing its malleability.
content: In 2017, while I was traveling through India, a friend from the northeastern state of Assam told me about the communities of Lost Tribe Jews in the neighboring state of Mizoram. Having grown up in a Jewish family without ever fully embracing the religion of my observant parents, I was intrigued and wanted to know more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Climate change was supposed to be a big issue this election. It wasn’t.
description: The Conservative Party moved leftward on the issue, effectively depriving the Liberals of a point to attack them on.
content: Canada may be known for its cold weather, but this summer, parts of the country were an inferno.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: The S.E.C. has opened an investigation into Activision Blizzard.
description: Activision has spent the summer grappling with accusations of sexual misconduct and workplace discrimination.
content: Activision Blizzard, the video game maker behind Call of Duty and other major franchises, said on Monday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating the company over “disclosures regarding employment matters and related issues.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Appeals Panel Overturns Army Judge’s Ruling on Torture
description: The decision on a case at the Guantánamo war court did not resolve the broader issue of whether prosecutors can use evidence obtained through torture.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — A Pentagon appeals panel on Monday threw out a ruling by an Army judge who found that evidence obtained during the torture of a defendant could be considered in determining pretrial matters in a death-penalty case at Guantánamo Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Ron Miles Headlines the Village Vanguard, at Last, as the Club Reopens
description: The cornetist led a quintet featuring Jason Moran, Bill Frisell, Thomas Morgan and Brian Blade as the 86-year-old establishment came back to life after its pandemic shutdown.
content: Ron Miles has a dusty and unvarnished sound on cornet that hints at his Rocky Mountain roots, and unlike your typical high-brass improviser, he hardly ever resorts to flash or big pronouncements. Onstage he’s unhurried, low-key and playing for the audience, yes, but not directly to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: At the Supreme Court, a Plea to Reveal Secret Surveillance Rulings
description: The justices will soon consider whether to hear a case arguing that the First Amendment requires disclosure of a secret court’s major rulings.
content: WASHINGTON — Last year, six months before he was nominated to be attorney general, Judge Merrick B. Garland wrote a forceful opinion on the importance of openness in the justice system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gardner
title: Nets Rookie Goes Apartment Shopping. Needs Ice Cream.
description: Day’Ron Sharpe, the 29th overall pick in this year’s N.B.A. draft, is making himself at home in New York as he gets ready for his first season alongside the Nets’ big stars.
content: Day’Ron Sharpe ducked his head under the doorway instinctively and scanned his eyes across the apartment. Its shape was a straight line running perpendicular to him with two bedrooms and a bathroom to his left; another bedroom and bathroom to his right; and a kitchen, living room and balcony opening up in bright light from big windows before him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Wok Adapter That Really Works
description: Wokmon funnels the flame from a gas burner, focusing the heat on the pan for better wok hei.
content: Glen Lee, an actor and inventor with a passion for cooking Chinese food, decided to try to make his home stove behave like a restaurant wok stove, with extra high heat concentrated at the base of a traditional round-bottom steel wok. He succeeded after many years and finally introduced the two-part gadget for gas stoves in 2019, with a curve-sided ring to focus the fire and a base to place over it to hold the pan. Originally the set came in a small and a medium size, for burners up to 3 3/4 inches in diameter. He has just introduced a large size for burners 4 to 5 1/2 inches. All the rings come with sets of legs; depending on the configuration of your burners and grates, setting them up securely can be tricky. To me it’s best if you cook with a wok frequently enough to want to keep one of these installed on a burner at all times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Most Americans disagree with the Supreme Court decision on Texas’ abortion ban, a poll finds.
description: Monmouth University Poll released its findings the same day the Supreme Court added hearings on a Mississippi abortion case.
content: A majority of Americans disapproves of the Supreme Court’s recent decision to allow a ban on most abortions to take effect in Texas, with key aspects of the law — such as empowering private citizens to enforce it through lawsuits — proving overwhelmingly unpopular, according to a national poll released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dmitri Alperovitch
title: America Is Being Held for Ransom. It Needs to Fight Back.
description: Businesses attacked. Data stolen. Miles of pipeline shut down. The scourge of ransomware is worse than ever.
content: The digital scourge known as ransomware — in which hackers shut down electronic systems until a ransom is paid — is worse than ever. Over the past few months, these attacks have leaked sensitive government data, thwarted the operations of hundreds of businesses and even temporarily shut down one of the United States’ biggest oil pipelines. The newest cybergang on the street — Groove, a motley crew of criminals that has already leaked 500,000 private passwords — has taken to threatening President Biden directly. (It’s likely, of course, to be sheer bluster.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Democrats Dealt a Blow on Immigration Plans
description: The Senate’s parliamentarian ruled that Democrats’ plan to give 8 million immigrants a path to citizenship could not be achieved through the reconciliation process.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate parliamentarian dealt a major setback on Sunday to Democrats’ plan to use their $3.5 trillion social policy bill to create a path to citizenship for an estimated 8 million undocumented immigrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Baltimore Flips the Script and Beats Kansas City
description: Lamar Jackson rushed for 107 yards and threw for 239 in a duel of former M.V.P. Award winners.
content: For three consecutive years, the schedule put Kansas City against Baltimore, a matchup broadcasters salivated over because of the teams’ explosive young quarterbacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich, Makiko Inoue and Hikari Hida
title: A Hard-Line Conservative Hopes to Be Japan’s First Female Leader
description: If Sanae Takaichi wins, it would be a milestone for the country. But some feminists hope that doesn’t happen.
content: TOKYO — Shinzo Abe, Japan’s longest-serving prime minister, often talked about creating a society in which women could “shine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Black
title: How to Make an Unloved Job More Attractive? Restaurants Tinker With Wages.
description: As they struggle to recruit workers, many owners are raising pay. But some are trying to go deeper, to make their business fairer and more humane.
content: Long before the pandemic persuaded so many restaurant employees to abandon the business, Corrinna Stum chafed at the illogic of the pay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Covid Vaccine Prompts Strong Immune Response in Younger Children, Pfizer Says
description: Vaccinated kids aged 5 to 11 showed evidence of protection against the virus, the company said. The data must be reviewed by the F.D.A. before children can be inoculated.
content: The Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine has been shown to be safe and highly effective in young children aged 5 to 11 years, the companies announced early Monday morning. The news sets the stage for authorization of the vaccine for younger children, possibly before the end of October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: Architecture and Design That Makes the Case for Discomfort
description: There are some visionaries who, in their refusal to follow the rules of convention, advance their fields and make us reconsider what we think we know.
content: There are some things all of us, no matter our aesthetic leanings, can agree on: A building is meant to protect us from the worst weather. A building should not collapse upon its inhabitants. But beyond that? Well, that is a matter of opinion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Pfizer’s pediatric vaccine
content: Pfizer said today that its Covid-19 vaccine was safe and highly effective in young children ages 5 to 11, with side effects similar to those observed in people ages 16 to 25.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Recap, Season 5, Episode 10: You Can’t Make an Omelet …
description: Eggs will be broken. The question amid all this conniving, though, is whose?
content: Chuck Rhoades is cooking eggs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: D.C. mayor says adults in schools and eligible student-athletes must get vaccinated by Nov. 1.
description: Mayor Muriel E. Bowser’s announcement eliminates an earlier testing option for school employees but retains exemptions for religious or health reasons.
content: All adults and eligible student-athletes who are regularly in schools and child care centers in Washington, D.C., must be fully vaccinated against Covid-19 by Nov. 1, the district’s mayor said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Vaccines, Stocks, Travel: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Cairo’s Antique Elevators, Glorious and Glitchy, Are Scenes of Love and Fear
description: For some Cairenes, the city’s geriatric lifts are beautiful marvels. Others consider them frustrating and frightening. Everyone has a story.
content: CAIRO — When you live in downtown Cairo, a neighborhood of European-meets-Egyptian facades in various states of faded grandeur, roundabouts whizzing with traffic and storefronts patchworked in riotously mismatched signage, it helps to cultivate a certain tolerance for features like relentless honking, rundown real estate and geriatric elevators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Ashley Southall
title: Man Threatened Life of Dominican President, Prosecutors Say
description: Enrique Figueroa, 47, is accused of writing a series of social media posts threatening President Luis Abinader.
content: Federal authorities in New York have arrested a man who they said had posted threats on the internet to kill Luis Abinader, the president of the Dominican Republic, who arrived on Saturday for the 76th General Assembly of the United Nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: The Senate’s rules enforcer said Democrats’ immigration plan could not be done through reconciliation.
description: The Senate’s top rules enforcer dealt a major setback on Sunday to Democrats’ plan to use their $3.5 trillion social policy bill to create a path to citizenship for an estimated 8 million undocumented immigrants, saying it violated the strict limits that apply to the measure.
content: The Senate’s top rules enforcer dealt a major setback on Sunday to Democrats’ plan to use their $3.5 trillion social policy bill to create a path to citizenship for an estimated 8 million undocumented immigrants, saying it violated the strict limits that apply to the measure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: The Conservative, Erin O’Toole, shifted left to broaden his party’s appeal.
description: Erin O’Toole, the leader of Canada’s Conservative Party and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s main rival, came to this campaign with very little name recognition among Canadians and with significant opposition from some members of his own party, particularly those in the Conservative power base of Alberta.
content: Erin O’Toole, the leader of Canada’s Conservative Party and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s main rival, came to this campaign with very little name recognition among Canadians and with significant opposition from some members of his own party, particularly those in the Conservative power base of Alberta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maxim Babenko
title: How to Vaccinate a Siberian Reindeer Herder
description: Covid has reached even the Yamal Peninsula in the Arctic. So vaccination teams are following, and finding ways to inoculate nomadic herders.
content: The Nenets are one of the few Indigenous minorities on the Yamal Peninsula in northwestern Siberia. Their lifestyle is nomadic, following the seasonal migrations of the reindeer they herd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Dry Eyes Afflict Many of Us. Here’s What to Do About It.
description: That gritty, itchy feeling in your eyes can arise from many causes, including too much screen time, and eye drops may only make it worse.
content: I didn’t have to wait until my ninth decade to appreciate how annoying dry eyes can be. And I was flummoxed by the plethora of products on pharmacy shelves that promise relief for a problem that affects about one in five adults. Perhaps you, like me, are among the many who have tried various over-the-counter remedies that didn’t help or sometimes made matters worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Gaia Pianigiani
title: New Zealand will ease Covid restrictions in Auckland.
description: Restaurants and cafes will reopen for takeout in the country’s second-most populous city. But Prime Minister Jacinda Arden said she remained committed to stamping out the virus.
content: New Zealand will ease coronavirus restrictions in Auckland, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said on Monday, ending nearly five weeks of the strictest lockdown in the country’s most populous city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips, Eshe Nelson and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Global Markets Swoon as Worries Mount Over Superpowers’ Plans
description: The S&P 500 closed down 1.7 percent over a number of jitters, like China’s sputtering real estate market and the phasing out of stimulus measures in the United States.
content: Investors on three continents dumped stocks on Monday, fretting that the governments of the world’s two largest economies — China and the United States — would act in ways that could undercut the nascent global economic recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Mark Landler and Heather Murphy
title: U.S. to Lift Pandemic Travel Restrictions, Easing Tension With Europe
description: Travelers who provide proof of full vaccination against the coronavirus before boarding a flight will be able to enter the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration will lift travel restrictions starting in November for foreigners who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus, reopening the country to thousands of people, including those who have been separated from family in the United States during the pandemic, and easing a major source of tension with Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: How the Cast Members of ‘Dear Evan Hansen’ Found Their Voices
description: Some stars of the movie musical, like Ben Platt and Amy Adams, were ready and eager to sing. Others, like Julianne Moore, got there eventually.
content: When you’re making a movie musical, you’re probably going to be looking for actors who can, you know, sing. It’s a truism that would seem to apply to “Dear Evan Hansen,” an adaptation of that Tony Award-winning Broadway musical, with a score by Benj Pasek and Justin Paul. It stars Ben Platt as the title character, a socially anxious teenager perpetuating a lie that has given him a welcome dose of popularity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Kate Christobek
title: Trump Organization Trial Is Scheduled for Next Summer, Judge Says
description: A Manhattan judge set a trial schedule for Allen Weisselberg and the Trump Organization on Monday that could coincide with the run-up to the 2022 midterm elections.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s family business and its longtime chief financial officer are tentatively scheduled to go on trial for tax crimes at the end of next summer, a time frame that would overlap with the closing stretch of the 2022 midterm campaign season, potentially influencing races where Mr. Trump’s presence could loom large.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: The Republican leading Wisconsin’s 2020 inquiry defends its legitimacy and warns of subpoenas.
description: Michael Gableman, a conservative former State Supreme Court Justice, declared that the state’s partisan inquiry into the election results was not meant to overturn President Biden’s victory.
content: The Wisconsin Republican leading the state’s partisan inquiry into the 2020 election results on Monday warned election clerks that they would face subpoenas if they did not cooperate and defended the investigation’s legitimacy by declaring that he was not seeking to overturn President Biden’s victory in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The State of Covid in the U.S.
description: We offer an update on the pandemic with four charts.
content: The U.S. has reached another potential turning point in the pandemic. But this is also a moment when the Covid-19 data is unusually tricky to read. In today’s newsletter, I’ll try to make sense of it, with help from four charts created by my colleague Ashley Wu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: U.S. Troops Are Still Deploying to Iraq, Even as Afghan War Ends
description: In the other country the United States invaded after 9/11, American troops continue to serve combat tours in harm’s way. Meet the soldiers headed for duty in Iraq.
content: FORT CARSON, Colo. — A taut line of soldiers crossed the sprawling Army post’s parade ground in the afternoon, hoisting flags draped with a rainbow of streamers from past deployments: Afghanistan, Iraq, Vietnam, Korea, Germany, France, Civil War battles and even skirmishes with Plains tribes on horseback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: At the Emmy Awards, TV Celebrates Its Own Survival
description: The telecast felt like a very private party — people seemed to be having fun, but the jollity didn’t really come through the screen.
content: As the positivity-signaling shows “Ted Lasso” and “Hacks” traded off comedy awards at the 73rd Primetime Emmy Awards on Sunday night, it was indicative of a past year that tried our souls and put us in the mood for a shared national tummy scratch. The traditional television industry, buffeted by the pandemic and endlessly losing ground to streaming video, has had it as bad as anyone, and the theme of the show — unremarkable, more or less efficient but still overly long — appeared to be, “Hey, we’ve all got jobs!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Law Student Armed With Shotgun Kills at Least Six at a Russian University
description: A social media post attributed to the gunman went up shortly before the attack, a misanthropic screed suggesting a lifelong fascination with violence.
content: MOSCOW — An 18-year-old law student wielding a shotgun went on a shooting spree on a Russian university campus on Monday, killing at least six people and wounding 19, according to state media, government officials and a university spokeswoman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Anthony Johnson, Actor Known for ‘Friday,’ Dies at 55
description: Mr. Johnson, whose other film credits include “House Party” and “Menace II Society,” died on Sept. 6, his agent said.
content: Anthony Johnson, an actor and comedian known for small but memorable roles in “Friday,” “House Party” and about two dozen other movies, died on Sept. 6. He was 55.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Progressives Worry Their Priorities Will Be Left Behind, Despite Biden’s Bold Words
description: The White House says it is committed to reducing gun violence, keeping abortion safe and legal, and protecting voting rights. But that has done little to ease anxiety among activists.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s passionate language on reducing gun violence, safeguarding access to abortion and protecting voting rights has lifted the hopes of progressives who were once wary of electing a traditionalist who champions compromise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Critical Race Theory: A Brief History’
description: In this lesson, students will look at the spread across the country of legislation opposed to critical race theory. Then, they will consider the impact of these bills on their own schools and learning.
content: Featured Article: “Critical Race Theory: A Brief History” by Jacey Fortin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Medicare Expansion Clashes With Health Care for the Poor as Budget Bill Shrinks
description: Under pressure to cut the bill’s cost, Democrats disagree over whether to offer more benefits to older Americans or to cover more of the working poor.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats are facing tough moral and political decisions over how to pursue their century-old dream of universal health care now that their ambitious $3.5 trillion social safety net bill will almost certainly have to be trimmed back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass and Mikael Olsson
title: An Architect Who’s Known for Aesthetic Purity and Counts Kanye West as a Client
description: The cult Swiss talent Valerio Olgiati creates austere, often concrete spaces that eschew references to history or place.
content: THE MONOLITHIC VILLA in the foothills of the Atlas Mountains an hour south of Marrakesh, Morocco, designed by Karl Fournier and Olivier Marty of the Paris-based architectural firm Studio KO as a French client’s holiday house, embodies contemporary Brutalism tinged by the Bauhaus. Shorn of ornament and minimally furnished, the fortresslike vacation home is all jutting red sandstone angles and expanses of glass, opening onto the cinnabar-hued landscape. But turn a corner and there looms what the architects refer to simply as the Wall, a two-story-high concrete cliff decorated with more than a dozen bas-relief circles in an array of sizes, some with abstract daisies at their centers. In so stark a context, it may be hard to understand why the duo, Fournier, 51, and Marty, 46, added such embellishments — until Marty offers a one-word explanation: “Olgiati.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Carpenter
title: Why Covid Vaccines for Kids Are Taking So Long
description: The F.D.A. needs a new system for responding to pandemics.
content: American parents are justifiably wondering why the United States hasn’t authorized Covid-19 vaccines for children under 12. Given the spread of the Delta variant and the recent increase in Covid-19 cases among children in the United States, their concerns are growing more urgent by the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: C.D.C. mandates measles vaccinations and quarantines for Afghan refugees.
description: Officials know of 16 confirmed cases of measles among Afghan evacuees and Americans who fled Afghanistan in recent weeks.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is requiring Afghan refugees to get vaccinated against measles and quarantine for 21 days, after some were found to have the highly contagious virus when they arrived in the country this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Cheung, Kaitlin Roberts, Luke Vander Ploeg, Lisa Chow, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: One Family’s Fight Against the Dixie Fire
description: As flames consumed rural towns in California this summer, it became clear how far residents would go to preserve their way of life.
content: Annie Correal, a reporter for The Times, has family in Indian Valley, in Northern California, roots which extend back to the 1950s. In August, the area, surrounded by thick forests, was pummeled by the enormous Dixie wildfire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Mnuchin’s Private Equity Fund Raises $2.5 Billion
description: The former Treasury secretary has attracted investment from Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund.
content: WASHINGTON — Steven Mnuchin has raised $2.5 billion at his new private equity fund, according to people familiar with the matter, attracting investments from sovereign wealth funds in the Middle East, including Saudi Arabia, where he traveled extensively as Treasury secretary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Jill Biden chases the president’s most elusive campaign promise: unity.
description: Eight months into President Biden’s term, both he and Jill Biden, the first lady, are finding that winning the “battle for the soul of the nation” is perhaps his most elusive campaign promise. In Washington, an outrage-driven approach to politics has replaced Mr. Biden’s rose-colored belief that bipartisan deal making can be an art form. As he tries to prove that this is still possible, his wife is not a bystander.

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: India plans to resume vaccine exports starting next month.
description: The announcement could help speed the delivery of Covid shots to poorer countries, five months after India halted shipments to fight its own outbreak.
content: India’s health minister said on Monday that the country would resume exports of Covid-19 vaccines, five months after halting shipments during its own devastating wave of infections.

title: In Russia Election Results, Online Votes Sweep Putin Opponents Aside
description: The official tally gave a strong parliamentary majority to President Vladimir V. Putin’s United Russia party. Opposition leaders cried foul, pointing to earlier signs of gains for their own candidates.
content: MOSCOW — Russia’s governing party has retained a two-thirds majority in the lower house of Parliament and claimed a sweeping victory in opposition-minded Moscow — a stark display of Kremlin power as the authorities on Monday announced the results of a nationwide election that opposition leaders denounced as blatantly falsified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: Seimone Augustus Found Her Voice Long Before Coaching
description: Augustus, laden with championship rings and now an assistant with the Los Angeles Sparks, first realized her true strength fighting for L.G.B.T.Q. rights.
content: The first time Seimone Augustus realized what she was capable of wasn’t when, as a 14-year-old, she landed on the cover of Sports Illustrated for Women next to the question, “Is She the Next Michael Jordan?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Hanania
title: ‘Just Trust the Experts,’ We’re Told. We Shouldn’t.
description: We need a new definition of expertise that relies more on  track records and less on credentials and the narrow forms of knowledge  they reward.
content: Much has been written about what the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan means for the future of that country and America’s global standing. But the failures of the war reveal a need for deeper introspection into what has gone wrong with American democracy and its institutions — including the story of failed expertise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: 2021 Emmy Winners: Complete List
description: The list of winners for the 73rd annual Emmy Awards.
content: Shows on streaming services dominated many people’s spare time during the pandemic. Many of those shows ended up dominating this year’s Emmys as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Best and Worst Moments of the 2021 Emmys
description: Streaming services dominated a ceremony that suggested that for all of TV’s evolution, some aspects of the Emmys will always be with us.
content: The Emmy Awards were back to being mostly in person after last year’s virtual ceremony, with TV’s best and brightest amassing in a classed-up event tent with banquet-style seating reminiscent of the Golden Globes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Deported by U.S., Haitians Are in Shock: ‘I Don’t Know This Country’
description: Haitians who lived abroad for years have been returned to a country in crisis that they barely recognize — often, they say, without a hearing.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The Haitian migrants had done well for themselves. Since leaving their country, many more than a decade ago, they had built lives in Chile, Brazil, Panama. They had homes and cars. They had stable jobs as bank tellers, welders, mine supervisors, gas station attendants.

content: As cider makers continue to hone their craft, food-friendly options have increased exponentially. Poured into stemware, the golden drinks shine at dinner; they are less filling than beer and lower in alcohol than wine. One way to explore a variety of ciders is with the new Cider Society subscription packages, offered quarterly, from Virtue Cider in Fennville, Mich.  The first one, for the fall season, has four bottles of the company’s new single-varietal ciders, a change of pace since most ciders are blends. Golden Russet, Spitz, Baldwin and Jonathan, all lightly sparkling and deliciously dry, have distinctive profiles. There’s a whisper of mellow sweetness in the Golden Russet and the Spitz, and the Baldwin suggests sauvignon blanc. Next up, the winter box will offer four ciders from a line called the Mitten Series, aged in bourbon and rye barrels.

content: Good morning. I was on a boat coming out of a marina in Brooklyn, idling along through Mill Basin along Four Sparrow Marsh, when a flock of black-crowned night herons took off from its perch on a ruined dock and flapped off silently toward the Belt Parkway. It was thrilling: birds being normal in a world where normal has been upended.
